#Text=Detect Freezer
#Text=Burn
#Text=Storing food in the freezer is an easy and safe way to keep food fresh for later use .
#Text=However , when outside air gets in contact with stored frozen food , it can lead to freezer burn , making the food unsightly and unappetizing to eat .

#Text=Freezer burn is relatively easy to spot , but there are a few sings to look out for when checking food for freezer burn , and some simply solutions to help slow down the process , to keep your stored foods as fresh as possible , for as long as possible .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Recognizing Freezer Burn
#Text=Look the food packaging .
#Text=An opening in the food packaging or a tear in the plastic indicate that the food has been exposed to cold , outside air , and has a higher chance of being freezer burned .
#Text=Inspect the food .
#Text=Remove the food from the packaging , and check the food for dry areas , areas of discoloration , and ice crystals .
#Text=Food with any of these qualities , is highly likely to be freezer burned .

#Text=The exact color of freezer burn discoloration varies depending on the food , but freezer burn tends to look white on poultry ( chicken ) , grayish-brown on meat ( steak ) , white on vegetables , and icy crystals formations on ice cream .
#Text=Patches of wrinkling on meat or vegetables are also an indication that your food might be freezer burned .
#Text=Smell the food .
#Text=Smell the food and see if you can detect an unpleasant plastic-y and stale “ freezer ” odor .
#Text=When fat from food comes in contact with air outside of its packaging and oxidizes , it creates the gross freezer flavor and smell we associate with freezer burn .
#Text=Check the date .
#Text=Store bought food is usually labeled with a storage date .
#Text=Check the label and determine if the food has been stored past this date .
#Text=If your food is past the labeled date , and has ice crystals , your food is most likely freezer burned .
#Text=Deal with the freezer burned food .
#Text=Freezer burned food is not unsafe to eat .
#Text=However , you can save a majority portion of the food you plan to eat by trimming off the freezer burned areas , and preparing and eating the rest of the food like normal .
#Text=If the freezer burn is widespread , throwing out the food may be the best option .
#Text=Even though the food is safe to eat , it will be flavorless , or have a strange flavor .
#Text=Freezer burned ice cream , will have small ice crystals formations on the surface , which are perfectly fine to eat , though not very appetizing .
#Text=Preventing Freezer Burn
#Text=Tightly seal your food .
#Text=Use freezer specific , sealable plastic bags to store food , and double-wrap your frozen items to stop water from evaporating from your food .
#Text=Food wrapped in store bought packaging usually lasts about 1-2 months in the freezer , but if you plan to store your food longer than that , consider wrapping your food more securely .
#Text=Try storing food in air-tight containers ( soups , broths , fruit ) or vacuum packaging ( fish , meats ) .
#Text=Repack opened store bought foods .
#Text=Once store bought frozen foods are opened , the moisture-vapor seal of the packaging is broken , no longer keeping moisture from the frozen food .
#Text=Because this barrier is broken , the food needs to be repackaged .

#Text=For example , putting a whole bag of opened veggies inside a freezer bag or taking frozen fish sticks out of an opened box and putting them into a small , freezer safe container , are efficient ways to repackage and store opened frozen foods .
#Text=Check the freezer temperature .
#Text=Your freezer temperature should be set to at least 0 degrees Fahrenheit , if not a bit lower .
#Text=Any temperature higher than zero , or inconsistent temperatures ( due to opening and closing the freezer door ) increases the risk of freezer burn .
#Text=Avoid storing food for too long .
#Text=All frozen food should be eaten within the recommended time period on the packaging labels .
#Text=Try labeling your frozen foods with a date to use and eat your food within the recommended time frame .
#Text=Remember : freezer burned food is not unsafe to eat ; it just means it may not be at its best quality .
#Text=Utilize ice dips .
#Text=Ice dipping is a very old method to preserve food .
#Text=You dip your raw food in water and allow the layering of water to freeze into an ice coating on the food .
#Text=Then you continue to dip the now ice coated food in water and again , allow the water to freeze into a layering of ice .
#Text=This dipping is done until there is a thick enough coating of ice over the food to protect it from penetrating outside air .
#Text=Fish is often dipped in ice for preservation .
#Text=Other raw foods that are preserved this way include chicken and other meat .
#Text=Ice dips are also utilized to help save on plastic packaging costs .
#Text=Tips
#Text=Wrap the item in freezer paper or store in a freezer bag to keep freezer burn at bay .
#Text=Freezer burned food wo n't taste good , but it is not inedible .
#Text=All it means , is that area of the food is lacking a lot of moisture .
